category_summary:
Major product announcements dominated AI discussions today. **Greg Brockman** confirmed **GPT-5.2 Pro** achieving milestones on Erdős mathematical problems and called the Codex integration a ["step function improvement"](/?date=2026-01-10&category=social#item-cbbfb0b12a22). **OpenAI** also [launched a HIPAA-ready healthcare platform](/?date=2026-01-10&category=social#item-6d6b511c0375) deployed at **UCSF** and **AdventHealth**.

- **Boris Cherny** from **Anthropic's Claude Code** team [open-sourced a code-simplifier](/?date=2026-01-10&category=social#item-c8e6845d3783) agent plugin, driving exceptional 1.6M engagement
- **Demis Hassabis** [announced](/?date=2026-01-10&category=social#item-3214d86bf501) **DeepMind** will integrate Gemini Robotics with **Boston Dynamics'** new Atlas robots
- **John Carmack's** #PaperADay delivered [deep technical analysis](/?date=2026-01-10&category=social#item-c962c07da932) on neural network architecture research

**Anthropic** dominated safety conversations with [Constitutional Classifiers research](/?date=2026-01-10&category=social#item-3eb87aaa4166) combining interpretability with jailbreak prevention. After [1,700 hours of red-teaming](/?date=2026-01-10&category=social#item-b55485cb8ff0), no universal jailbreak was found—a significant validation. **Santiago Pino** offered a grounded counterpoint to agent hype, [arguing XGBoost models](/?date=2026-01-10&category=social#item-a693c19b5f3f) still generate 10x more revenue than AI agents in practice.

items.title:
#PaperADay 2
2026: Deep Delta Learning https://t.co/nKj9NE1ri6

The standard residual network blocks...
items.content:
#PaperADay 2
2026: Deep Delta Learning https://t.co/nKj9NE1ri6

The standard residual network blocks are limited to adding on top of the existing state, which limits the expressivity of each layer. It is still a universal approximator, but we can always hope for function blocks that are more parameter / performance / training efficient.

This paper proposes a new block based on generalizing the Householder matrix so that the state can be partially or completely collapsed onto (or past) a hyperplane in addition to having new values added on top. This allows information along a vector to be multiplicatively erased while a different vector is added.

This is an all-math, no-experiments paper, which usually doesn’t bode well.

The same scalar gates both the directional collapse and the value addition. Those might be better off independent, like input and forget gates in an LSTM.

When the gating vector is 0.0, the layer is an identity. At 1.0, the previous state has been collapsed onto the learnable hyperplane before adding the new value, and at 2.0 the previous state has been reflected across the hyperplane.

They force the gate scalar to be bounded between 0 and 2 by using 2*sigmoid, but that means that default initializations will tend to project everything onto the plane, collapsing values quickly, and you can’t actually reach a perfect identity.

Is it actually necessary to bound the gate value? Letting it extend past those bounds just results in scaling along the vector, and avoids the sigmoid gradient issues.

They normalize the reflection direction after calculating it with an MLP, which can cause some learning dynamics issues since the weight norm can grow without bound, which reduces the effective learning rate with Adam.
items.author: @ID_AA_Carmack
items.summary: John Carmack's deep analysis of 'Deep Delta Learning' paper on generalizing Householder matrices for neural networks, discussing expressivity limitations of residual networks and proposing new blocks
items.reasoning: Exceptional technical depth from legendary programmer, #PaperADay series provides accessible analysis of cutting-edge research, high engagement (415 likes), rare combination of credibility and technical insight

items.title:
My favorite AI models/tools for different tasks right now:

1) Go-to starter: Claude Opus 4.5 - I co...
items.content:
My favorite AI models/tools for different tasks right now:

1) Go-to starter: Claude Opus 4.5 - I continue to be stunned by its capabilities. It gets me. It passes the vibe check with flying colors. It matches my writing at 85-93%. I added a Claude Max account to my Team account just to use it more (and because Anthropic hates Team users). Downsides are that it runs out of context fast and that it jumps to action (like making a slide deck) too often when I don't want it to. 

2) Daily doer: Claude Code - I feel like a powerful conductor, wielding multiple terminals, building anything that pops into my mind, morphing my computer into the right interface at the right time. Mostly a terminal user, but will eventually go into Chrome more.

3) Long tasks with lots of context: Google Gemini 3 Pro/NotebookLM - I remain obsessed with NotebookLM and love that it takes in links. I regularly upload YouTube links to those 2h or 4h long podcasts and 'talk' to the podcast guest. 200K tokens in Claude and ChatGPT just runs out too fast.

4) Image anything - Nano Banana Pro. Holy cow. I made a fun PPT for my team and used NBP to make every single dynamic slide background. Infographics are the best, even with a few text issues. Would not call it enterprise-grade due to text inconsistencies. 

5) Video - tie between Sora and Veo 3, with Veo 3 slightly ahead. This is not a common use case for me. Really just to make memes. I prioritize convenience very highly here, and the Sora app is easy. I don't scroll the Sora app, however. Used it for 3 days and stopped. Maybe I'm not the right demographic. 

6) Voice anything - Whisper API, followed by Wispr Flow and Otter AI tied for second. Gemini a distant third. Anthropic fading into the deep darkness in fourth and forgotten place. Siri buried under the floorboards.

7) Talking to multiple documents - NotebookLM

8) Extra efficiency hacks - Claude Skills, Claude brain dump folder for terminal comms, Wispr Flow into multiple CC terminals, Stream Deck with AI shortcuts, prompt text replacement shortcuts, Oculus Quest headset for extra focus, airplane mode, blue light blocking glasses, headlamp (I know that last one sounds insane)
items.author: @alliekmiller
items.summary: Comprehensive review of favorite AI tools: Claude Opus 4.5 for general use, Claude Code for terminal-based building, Gemini/NotebookLM for long context, Nano Banana Pro for images, Sora/Veo 3 for video, Whisper for voice, plus efficiency hacks

items.title: I heard this a lot this week at CES. The robots for the home are at least two years away. Probably f...
items.content:
I heard this a lot this week at CES. The robots for the home are at least two years away. Probably five, many say.

Met with @BradTempleton who was an early genius working for @waymo.

He reminded me again that I was over my skis when it comes to Tesla Robotaxi.

But I did tell everyone my date is April and not end of year like Elon once promised.

He hates when I talk about dates and gave me a good class in why no one knows when Autonomy is fully solved.

I do have data about what the fleet is doing.

Which is why I am always on the Tesla community spaces.

And have the best Tesla list here on X.

Lists are about to get a lot more important.

Think of them as ground truth. You see it all. Keeps you grounded to reality.

@GaryShapiro did a gracious stop and talk to me for a few precious moments in the hallway.

He runs the show and has always been a gracious man.

I can’t imagine a better leader for the tech industry.

And his show kicked off the autonomous age. Mercedes gave me its first ride in its first AI vehicle here years ago.

Gary deserves credit for supporting autonomous vehicles from the beginning.

But Brad has me thinking through the difference between intuition and knowledge.

Reevaluating everything in the knowledge category because mistakes were found in my thinking.

I know of breakthroughs inbound. 

But I do have to admit that I don’t know when Tesla Robotaxi will be turned on without humans on board.

Data solves all arguments.

Elon will be forced to slow down until he has enough data. He can’t afford to see the system make a mistake, Brad told me that’s why he doesn’t see it shipping soon.

The lawyers won’t let it ship until it is done. Truth is everyone on the team realizes it has to be perfect when turned on.

Or very very close.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Comprehensive CES reflection: home robots 2-5 years away, conversation with Brad Templeton (Waymo pioneer) about Tesla Robotaxi timeline uncertainty, importance of data for autonomy decisions, Elon's need to prove system safety before launch.
items.reasoning: High-value first-hand CES insight from tech industry observer, substantive discussion of autonomous vehicle timelines with credible source (Brad Templeton), practical analysis of Tesla's constraints. Very high engagement (21.8K views).

items.title: Neuro-symbolic AI refers to systems that integrate neural networks, which handle pattern recognition...
items.content:
Neuro-symbolic AI refers to systems that integrate neural networks, which handle pattern recognition from data, with symbolic reasoning, which applies logical rules from a knowledge base to ensure outputs follow domain-specific constraints.

In such systems, neural outputs often conflict with these rules on complex tasks, and fixing those inconsistencies typically requires costly searches during inference.

This AAAI 2025 Best Paper builds on *abductive learning*—a framework where abduction, or inferring the most plausible fixes based on logic, corrects neural mistakes—and introduces a reflection mechanism: a vector generated alongside the neural output that pinpoints likely errors by learning from the knowledge base via a reinforcement approach like REINFORCE, which optimizes policies using rewards.

During training, this vector is abduced directly from the rules without extra labels, narrowing the space for symbolic fixes and making the process far more efficient.

Tests on puzzles like Sudoku and graph optimization problems reveal it achieves higher accuracy with less data and faster reasoning than prior methods, while handling both symbolic inputs like digits and sub-symbolic ones like images.

Read with ChapterPal: https://t.co/g5ambSBqMq

Download PDF: https://t.co/UECR16RKSN
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Detailed technical breakdown of AAAI 2025 Best Paper on neuro-symbolic AI. Paper introduces reflection mechanism for abductive learning, combining neural networks with symbolic reasoning. Shows improved accuracy with less data on puzzles like Sudoku.
items.reasoning: High-quality technical summary of award-winning research from @burkov. Substantive explanation of novel AI architecture combining neural and symbolic approaches. Original technical insight.

items.title: There's nothing worse than having to stop what you are doing to fix an issue somewhere else in your ...
items.content:
There's nothing worse than having to stop what you are doing to fix an issue somewhere else in your code.

This happens all the time.

Context switching is still a huge problem. Every time this happens, you can easily waste 20 minutes getting back in the flow.

The team at Verdent AI showed me what they are doing to solve this, and it's pretty interesting:

Their core idea is to have parallel workstreams that don't blow up your main context.

Here's what that looks like in practice when you are using their tool to write code:

1. Tasks - You can spin up separate conversation threads without losing your primary work. One task is debugging, another is exploring a new feature, and a third is doing research. Switch between them instantly.

2. Workspaces - Each workspace is an isolated coding environment with its own branch, commit history, and modifications. You can literally build two different implementations of the same feature side by side, then decide which one to merge.

I really like the idea of having parallelization baked into the tool itself. Software development doesn't work linearly: you're always juggling multiple things at once.
items.author: @svpino
items.summary: Santiago Pino details Verdent AI's approach to context switching in AI coding: parallel Tasks, isolated Workspaces with separate branches, enabling multiple implementation streams simultaneously
items.reasoning: Detailed technical breakdown of novel AI coding tool architecture addressing real developer pain point, moderate engagement

items.title: @HanchungLee @paulbettner This^. When building agents and skills, helpful to think about whether you...
items.content:
@HanchungLee @paulbettner This^. When building agents and skills, helpful to think about whether you want them to see the parent context or not. You want an uncorrelated context window for unrelated tasks, unbiased criticism, if you want the agent to think more independently, etc. Otherwise the parent context essentially prompt-injects the subagent. 

You can do that with fork-context: true for skills, or use a subagent to get forked context by default

items.title:
Just got back from CES 2026. Here's what actually stood out:

Robot vacuums and lawnmowers were EVER...
items.content:
Just got back from CES 2026. Here's what actually stood out:

Robot vacuums and lawnmowers were EVERYWHERE. The market is saturated.

Facial recognition is expanding beyond security—bird feeders, pet food dispensers, doorbell cameras. Vision AI is becoming ambient. Samsung fridge was a standout.

Voice-enabled devices were present but a bit underwhelming. Tested a voice-enabled air fryer from Emerson. We're not there yet in hardware (didn't help that the internet at CES was non-functional), but I still think voice will explode in 2026.

Still a lot of "smart" tech, like Govee lights (see: below pic). Very rules-based traditional systems, similar to Nest. 

LLM integration was surprisingly low. Exception: cute physical AI companions. Sharp's Poketomo is a 4.5" fuzzy meerkat with a slew of little outfits that chats with you. Also got a private demo of Razer's Project Ava, a 5.5" hologram desk companion powered by Grok.

Health tech and accessibility tech had strong showings. Met a startup from Japan measuring standing strength. Another from the Netherlands doing macro tracking. Another from France that created a monitor for dyslexic users.

If you're building in consumer HW tech, pay attention to what's NOT saturated, especially in health and home. And steal best practices from the best-in-class software conversations on social.
items.author: @alliekmiller
items.summary: CES 2026 observations: saturated robot vacuum market, expanding facial recognition, underwhelming voice devices, low LLM integration in hardware, strong health/accessibility tech
items.reasoning: Detailed market analysis from industry observer, identifies gaps and opportunities in AI hardware integration, practical insights for builders

"AI-Native LLM Security — Thre...
items.content:
New Release from @PacktDataML — available at https://t.co/uIYwY3vQd9

"AI-Native LLM Security — Threats, Defenses, and Best Practices for Building Safe and Trustworthy AI"

𝘽𝙤𝙤𝙠 𝘿𝙚𝙨𝙘𝙧𝙞𝙥𝙩𝙞𝙤𝙣:
"Adversarial AI attacks present a unique set of security challenges, exploiting the very foundation of how AI learns. This book explores these threats in depth, equipping cybersecurity professionals with the tools needed to secure generative AI and LLM applications. Rather than skimming the surface of emerging risks, it focuses on practical strategies, industry standards, and recent research to build a robust defense framework.

Structured around actionable insights, the chapters introduce a secure-by-design methodology, integrating threat modeling and MLSecOps practices to fortify AI systems. You’ll discover how to leverage established taxonomies from OWASP, NIST, and MITRE to identify and mitigate vulnerabilities. Through real-world examples, the book highlights best practices for incorporating security controls into AI development life cycles, covering key areas such as CI/CD, MLOps, and open-access LLMs."

items.title: @mtavitschlegel I didn’t see any episode step counts listed, are they in the tens-of-thousands for s...
items.content:
@mtavitschlegel I didn’t see any episode step counts listed, are they in the tens-of-thousands for successful runs on the ant? What were your step rates like?

The ant’s limbs may be modeled in 3D, but that is irrelevant to the environment — it is just a 2D point that has a very funny control scheme.

I conflated the grid and ant observations, but relative XY positions for the targets is even easier than a one-hot grid. I get the reasoning behind just going one small step beyond a grid world to make a minimal demonstration of the concept, I just suspect that many people that saw the video go by on X ascribed more capability to the agent than was actually there.

I understand the boundaries of the options are learned, but the expert trajectories were generated with 1-of-4 steering, and the agent only has to classify the actions into 1-of-4 options, or just any permutation of the original set. If it was given the capability to learn 16 actions, would it find new divisions? That is directly relevant to my interests: if an agent learns from scratch, can it usefully identify the emergent longer temporal action sets in its own behavior, versus from an expert that explicitly had categorical behaviors.

Thank you for the clarifications!
items.author: @ID_AA_Carmack
items.summary: Carmack's technical follow-up on RL agents discussing episode step counts, ant environment modeling, and whether agents can learn emergent action sets from scratch vs from expert demonstrations
items.reasoning: Deep technical discussion on reinforcement learning from John Carmack, explores important question about emergent behavior learning

items.title:
if you're also interested in detecting model cheating, just heard about CapBencher from @tksii

Pape...
items.content:
if you're also interested in detecting model cheating, just heard about CapBencher from @tksii

Paper: https://t.co/EunJxiJ1Wt

"The core trick is to intentionally cap the best achievable accuracy (Bayes accuracy) so that even a fully capable model shouldn't exceed the ceiling. If a model does beat it, it's a strong signal of contamination, leakage, or cheating. We also show experiments this idea works very well when we want to detect data contamination or leaderboard hacking. 

Our idea is an improvement over naively adding label noise to the answers, because the label noise approach will weaken the ability to evaluate the capabilities of LLMs and track their improvements.  "
items.author: @swyx
items.summary: Discussion of CapBencher tool for detecting model cheating/data contamination on benchmarks by capping best achievable accuracy. If model exceeds Bayes accuracy ceiling, signals contamination.
items.reasoning: Technical tool addressing important benchmark integrity problem. Relevant to model evaluation methodology.

items.title: @TeksEdge Now, the Ray-Bans cannot do a full holodeck. They are just not going to have optics good e...
items.content:
@TeksEdge Now, the Ray-Bans cannot do a full holodeck. They are just not going to have optics good enough to do that, or the computing power you need to serve a holodeck device.

The best devices for that are the middleweight glasses, such as:
1. The Xreal
2. The Viture
3. The RayNeo

These have a birdbath optic or a hybrid birdbath optic. While they are a little thicker and heavier up front, they provide a much better image. So, that is going to be one of the form factors. However, this current form factor (which has 4K displays in each eye) is far superior to anything you are going to see in glasses.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Detailed analysis of AR glasses form factors: Ray-Bans limited vs. birdbath optic glasses (Xreal, Viture, RayNeo) offering 4K displays.
items.reasoning: Substantive technical comparison of AR glasses technologies with specific product knowledge and optics insight.

For most tasks, I don't think it is a good idea to j...
items.content:
By the way, Verdent also supports a Plan Mode.

For most tasks, I don't think it is a good idea to jump straight into code generation.

Instead, spend time thinking through the problem first and write down as many details as possible. Give this to the tool and let it ask clarifying questions, identify gaps, and generate a structured plan for you.

That's how you'll make the most progress.
items.author: @svpino
items.summary: Santiago recommends using Plan Mode in Verdent to think through problems before code generation, letting the tool ask clarifying questions and generate structured plans

items.title:
I don't trust most AI coding agents with production code.

Last week I had to refactor an authentica...
items.content:
I don't trust most AI coding agents with production code.

Last week I had to refactor an authentication endpoint serving 50K+ active sessions. 

One bug and we're logging users out or worse, exposing tokens.

Tested Junie from Jet Brains on it.

𝙏𝙝𝙚 𝙩𝙖𝙨𝙠: Add OAuth2 support alongside our existing JWT setup without breaking current sessions.

𝙒𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙖𝙘𝙩𝙪𝙖𝙡𝙡𝙮 𝙝𝙖𝙥𝙥𝙚𝙣𝙚𝙙:
> Before writing anything, it pulled up 15+ files - session manager, middleware, error handlers - and explained how they connected

> Suggested moving auth into a separate service layer. I asked why. It said: "Isolates authentication from routing. Easier to test, easier to swap providers later"

> Proposed storing refresh tokens in the database. I pushed back - wanted in-memory for speed. It adjusted without restarting

The code wasn't perfect. 

I rewrote the error handling myself. But I understood every decision it made, which meant I could actually review it properly.

𝙊𝙣𝙚 𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙄 𝙙𝙞𝙙𝙣'𝙩 𝙚𝙭𝙥𝙚𝙘𝙩: 
You can run Junie tasks directly from GitHub. I triggered a refactor from a PR comment while I was reviewing other code. 

It worked asynchronously, didn't need my IDE open.

This is the first AI agent I've used where I actually read the output instead of just hoping it works. 

Try it yourself: https://t.co/pMUBJTXsgs
items.author: @AlphaSignalAI
items.summary: Detailed review of JetBrains' Junie AI coding agent for production auth refactoring task (OAuth2 + JWT). Notes agent explained reasoning, suggested architecture improvements, and allowed interactive refinement.
items.reasoning: Substantive real-world test case though somewhat promotional. Provides detailed evaluation of AI coding agent capabilities.

items.title:
People love to see what it takes to build software for large companies.

That's how I personally lea...
items.content:
People love to see what it takes to build software for large companies.

That's how I personally learn the most: by reading about what other people did to solve specific problems.

That's how I organized my entire AI/ML Engineering program:

I tell one story after another, with very specific recommendations about what you should do when building production systems.

The first session starts with how you should frame problems. The final session ends with specific advanced techniques for building continual learning systems.

I try to take you through the entire process and give you the blueprint I've used for the last 30 years.

The next cohort starts February 2, 2026.

You can join at https://t.co/iZifcK7UTF.

items.title: ChapterPal is the best way to learn AI, machine learning, and computing from scratch. It has a colle...
items.content:
ChapterPal is the best way to learn AI, machine learning, and computing from scratch. It has a collection of beginner-friendly and hands-on books that are available to all registered users, including free-tier subscribers.

One advantage of reading with ChapterPal is that you can ask questions to the AI tutor, who sees what you have already read and answers your questions in your specific reading context. Free-tier subscribers get 20 Q&A's per month for free.

ChapterPal also comes with a collection of curricula grouping the most important research articles on various topics like computer vision, reinforcement learning, and neural image generation.

The reader app generates quizzes and puzzles that make the reading process active, which provably contributes to better retention.
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Burkov promotes ChapterPal learning platform for AI/ML with AI tutor and quizzes
items.reasoning: Promotional content for educational product

items.title:
@AugusteCom30151 I've been pretty consistent I think

I believe that everyone can be and do whatever...
items.content:
@AugusteCom30151 I've been pretty consistent I think

I believe that everyone can be and do whatever they want as long as it doesn't reduce other people's freedoms

So for ex you can identify as an Apache attack helicopter, but you can't force people to call you that because that limits ppl's freedoms

I also believe that you should make it easy to start and run businesses, because they create prosperity for society

And then I think basics like infrastructure (roads, train tracks etc) and healthcare and education should be mostly free for everyone so everyone can start an equal footing in life regardless of wealth

After that you need a mostly free market so people can play in that market on equal footing

But then it should be equality of opportunity, not equality of outcome

There's winners and losers, and that's nature and we should mirror ourselves after nature

I've believed most of this since forever
items.author: @levelsio
items.summary: Levelsio agrees with meme about beliefs
items.reasoning: Part of longer thread about personal philosophy, not AI-related

One message becomes many variations → perfect for A/B ...
items.content:
The real advantage is scale and consistency.

One message becomes many variations → perfect for A/B testing.
Every output matches your voice → no more generic AI.

Teams get two big benefits:

→ Small teams gain scale they could never hire for
→ Larger teams stay perfectly consistent across channels

Available today in the US, Canada, Australia, and New Zealand.
